name: Track AI Agent token usage and estimate costs in Google Sheets

user.name: Solomon
user.bio: Teaching at the Scrapes Academy (see link below). For business inquiries: automations.solomon@gmail.com | Telegram: t.me/salomaoguilherme | LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/guisalomao/

description:
![image.png](fileId:1659)
### This n8n template demonstrates how to obtain token usage from AI Agents and places the data into a spreadsheet that calculates the estimated cost of the execution.

Obtaining the token usage from AI Agents is tricky, because it doesn't provide all the data from tool calls. This workflow taps into the workflow execution metadata to extract token usage information.

Works well with OpenAI, Google and Anthropic. Other LLM providers might need small tweaks.

### How it works
1. The AI Agent executes and then calls a subworkflow to calculate the token usage.
2. The data is stored in Google Sheets
3. The spreadsheet has formulas to calculate the estimated cost of the execution.

### How to use
- The AI Agent is used as an example. Feel free to replace this with other agents you have.
- Call the subworkflow AFTER all the other branches have finished executing.

### Requirements
- LLM account (OpenAI, Gemini...) for API usage.
- Google Drive and Sheets credentials
- n8n API key of your instance

data.details: The Execute Workflow node can be used when you want your workflow to treat another workflow as a step in your flow. It allows you to modularize your workflows and have a single source of truth for series of actions you perform often.

parameters.text: Help me test something and output the text "This is a test workflow" after calling the think tool twice.

parameters.content:
## Wait for the workflow to finish before calling the subworkflow
If the execution is still running, too much data is retrieved and it becomes messy.

So put this node at the end of the workflow and disable the option `Wait For Sub-Workflow Completion`.

That way you have to retrieve less data and it's easier to retrieve the token usage.

`{{ $workflow.id }}` is an expression to get the current workflow id. Change this if your subworkflow is in a separate file.
After the main workflow calls the subworkflow, you'll be able to see the total tokens in the Executions spreadsheet.

nodes.name: Sum Token Totals - aggregate by model

parameters.content:
## Limitations
### 1. This workflow doesn't account for [Prompt caching](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/prompt-caching)
If you're consecutively sending similar prompts to OpenAI it'll automatically use Cached Tokens to reduce the cost of your requests.

So our cost estimates will have a higher value than the actual cost.

Other providers like Anthropic and Google have similar mechanisms.



### 2. Not tested with audio or video files
This workflow was tested with text and images, but no tests were made with audio files or videos.



### 3. The cost is an estimate
In the spreadsheet you can see the total cost of the requests, but that is only an estimate.

If you do batch requests, prompt caching or other techniques to reduce cost, the estimate might be higher than the actual cost.

This is an example AI Agent.

Use this only to understand how to call the subworkflow and obtain the token amount.

## Where to find LLM pricing?
You can enter each provider's website or use one of these:
- [llm-price.com](https://llm-price.com)
- [llm-prices.com](https://llm-prices.com)
- [llmprices.dev](https://llmprices.dev/)
- [LLM Price Check](https://llmpricecheck.com/)
- [OpenRouter Models](https://openrouter.ai/models)

## Make a copy of this Sheets file
üëâ [**[TEMPLATE] Calculate LLM Token Usage**](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1c9CeePI6ebNnIKogyJKHUpDWT6UEowpH9OwVtViadyE/edit?usp=sharing)

There are two sheets in this file:
1. Executions
Avoid changing the green columns. They have formulas on the header rows.

2. LLM Pricing
Update this list with the LLM models you are using

### This n8n template demonstrates how to obtain token usage from AI Agents and places the data into a spreadsheet that calculates the estimated cost of the execution.

Obtaining the token usage from AI Agents is tricky, because it doesn't provide all the data from tool calls. This workflows taps into the workflow execution metadata to extract token usage information.

- The AI Agent executes and then calls a subworkflow to calculate the token usage.
- The data is stored in Google Sheets
- The spreadsheet has formulas to calculate the estimated cost of the execution.

### How to use
- The AI Agent is used as an example. Feel free to replace this with other agents you have.
- Call the subworkflow AFTER all the other branches have finished executing.
